title: Spinoza: The Philosopher Too Dangerous for God
description:
Baruch Spinoza was one of the most dangerous thinkers of all time. Excommunicated from his Jewish community and condemned by Christians, Spinoza rejected the idea of a personal God, denied miracles, and argued that scripture was man-made, not divine. His radical philosophy paved the way for secularism, modern atheism, and even influenced Einstein’s view of the universe. But why was he feared so much? In this episode, I explore the life, ideas, and lasting impact of the philosopher who redefined God and paid the price for it.

title: Why So Many Gods Have Birth Stories | One Idea, Many Myths
description:
Across cultures and centuries, gods are often born in extraordinary ways. This episode explores why divine figures so often arrive through birth stories and what these shared myths reveal about how humans understand meaning, beginnings, and the sacred.

title: When the Gods Walked Away
description:
Across cultures, some gods didn’t fall or die, they chose to leave. This episode explores ten deities who withdrew from the world and what their departures reveal about responsibility, meaning, and life after divine authority.

title: Explanation Addiction: When Relief Replaces Reality
description:
Why do explanations feel so comforting even when they aren’t true? In this episode, we explore how the brain becomes addicted to relief, why uncertainty hurts, and how the desire for explanation can quietly replace reality itself. This is a deep dive into belief, comfort, and the hidden psychology behind why answers feel so good.

title: Gods Lost to Time: 5 Myths Worth Remembering
description:
Ancient civilizations left behind powerful myths that shaped how humans understood life, death, gods, and the cosmos. Many were nearly erased by conquest, canonization, and time. In this episode, we recover five lost myths from the ancient world, exploring forgotten gods, suppressed stories, and the worldviews history pushed aside. These myths reveal how humanity once made sense of existence long before modern religion and scripture took center stage.

title: The Ache of Eden: Why Every Culture Imagined a Golden Age
description:
Across every culture, humans tell stories of a perfect world we somehow lost. This episode explores why we long for “lost worlds,” why Eden still haunts us, and what these myths reveal about the human mind. By tracing the universal ache for a better beginning, we uncover the deeper truth behind paradise itself.

title: The Goddess Who Died: 3 Lessons From the First Resurrection Myth
description:
Inanna’s Descent is the world’s oldest resurrection myth and one of the most psychologically revealing stories ever recorded. In this episode, I explore what her journey into the underworld teaches us about surrender, empathy, and the cost of avoiding hard truths. Three ancient lessons with modern power.

description:
Boethius is one of history's forgotten heroes. He was adored for over a thousand years and then lost to time, but his lessons on how to face death should be required reading for us all!

title: The King Who Collected the World | And Its Destruction
description:
I am out of town for a while and so this episode has been repurposed from previous work I have done. I hope you enjoy, and look forward to connecting when I am back!

King Ashurbanipal was a rare kind of ruler. He was both a ruthless warlord and a devoted scholar. He built the first great library in history, a vast collection of knowledge that preserved literature, medicine, astronomy, and law from ancient civilizations. But like so many centers of learning, the Library of Ashurbanipal was lost to war. Today, we uncover the forgotten story of the warrior-king who tried to save knowledge but couldn’t save his own empire.

title: The Philosophy That Killed Fear
description:
I am out of town for a while and so this episode and Saturday's episode are repurposed from previous work I have done. I hope you enjoy, and look forward to connecting when I am back!

Let's explore the philosophy of Epicurus, the ancient Greek thinker who challenged traditional views of the gods and introduced ideas that resonate with modern wisdom still today. From his famous Trilemma on the problem of evil to his pursuit of ataraxia - I dive into his views on divine indifference, natural explanations, and the legacy of his teachings in philosophy, ethics, and secular thought.

title: The Wisdom of Tricksters: Loki, Hermes, and Coyote
description:
This episode dives into three of history’s greatest tricksters - Loki, Hermes, and Coyote, to reveal the uncomfortable truths these mythic rule-breakers expose. Across Norse, Greek, and Indigenous traditions, the trickster shows that blind spots, rigid rules, and repeated failures teach us more than obedience ever could. Here’s why cultures fear them, need them, and why their wisdom still matters.

title: The Great Demotions: The Story of How the Universe Got Bigger
description:
This is the story of how humanity discovered the universe was far bigger and far stranger than we ever imagined. From Copernicus to Galileo to Hubble to JWST, each revelation shrank our specialness but expanded our sense of wonder. This episode traces those moments when reality overturned our assumptions and invited us into a truer, more awe-filled cosmos.

title: When Love Defies Logic
description:
When love defies logic, it reshapes everything - our choices, our stories, and even the worlds we build. In this episode, I explore three of the most powerful cinematic moments where love breaks every rule. We uncover why love isn’t irrational at all, and how it may be the most intelligent force in the universe.

This video contains brief excerpts from The Matrix Reloaded (2003), What Dreams May Come (1998), and Interstellar (2014). All clips are used under Fair Use for the purpose of commentary, analysis, and educational discussion. No copyright infringement is intended. All rights belong to their respective owners.

title: The Monster in the Labyrinth Isn’t What You Think
description:
This episode explores the labyrinth not as a prison, but as a mirror. From Theseus and the Minotaur to Jung and Turner, we trace why every descent, mythic or personal, demands that we face the monster within. The only way out is through.

title: 3 Questions That Change Everything: The Three-Fold Lens
description:
When life feels heavy or unclear, it’s usually not because we lack answers, but it’s because we’re asking the wrong questions. In this episode, I share The Three-Fold Lens: three simple questions that help you see any situation with clarity and honesty. Use this when you’re overwhelmed, stuck, or unsure what to do next.

title: The Fear of Being Forgotten | Humanity’s Need to Haunt!
description:
The dead don't haunt us, we haunt them. Let's rethink the "Ghost Story!" This episode explores how humanity learned to make meaning out of death. We’ll uncover why every culture tells ghost stories, and how forgetting is the real death.

title: Humanity’s Deepest Illusion | The Soul
description:
From ancient Egypt’s ka to Plato’s psyche and the Christian soul, this episode traces how humanity turned divinity inward - creating the idea that something eternal lives within us. Let's discuss when gods became human, when spirit became self, and how the invention of the soul still shapes who we believe we are.

description:

title: The Danger of Seeing Too Clearly | Alan Watts on Awareness
description:
What happens when you see too clearly? In this Alan Watts inspired episode, we explore the hidden cost of awareness - why sensitivity, empathy, and deep perception can isolate you, and how to live awake in a sleeping world with peace, clarity, and compassion.

title: The Philosophy of Silence | Why It Matters More Than Ever
description:
Let's explore silence! Silence is not emptiness, but as a presence that shapes everything we know. From the wisdom of mystics to the findings of modern neuroscience, silence has always been humanity’s oldest language. It teaches, heals, and reveals what constant noise hides. Sometimes, the most powerful sound is the one we finally stop to hear.

title: The Morality of Power | When Humans Played Gods
description:
What happens when humanity gains the power of the gods but not the wisdom to use it? From myth to modern science, this episode explores how creation and destruction have always walked hand in hand. We’ll connect the Tower of Babel, Frankenstein, and the atomic age to today’s struggles with AI, biotechnology, and human ambition. Join me as we ask the timeless question - can we handle the power we’ve created?

title: Skepticism with a Smile | The Laughing Philosopher
description:
What if you couldn’t tell whether you were dreaming or awake? Over two thousand years ago, the Chinese philosopher Zhuangzi asked that same question and laughed. His famous Butterfly Dream challenges everything we think we know about truth, perception, and the limits of reason. In this episode, I explore how his playful skepticism still speaks to our world of illusions today.

title: How To Escape the Dark! | Plato's Allegory of the Cave
description:
Plato’s Allegory of the Cave is one of the most powerful stories in all of philosophy. In this episode, I explore what it means to mistake shadows for truth and what it costs to step into the light. Along the way, I connect Plato’s vision to psychology, politics, religion, and even modern media. This is a journey from darkness to light, and it still matters just as much today as it did 2,400 years ago.

title: The Myth of Prometheus | The Price of Progress
description:
Welcome to Sharing Fire, Episode 1! Please subscribe and engage if this is the kind of content you'd like to see more of. In this episode I cover the myth of prometheus - the Titan who defied Zeus by stealing fire from the gods and giving it to humankind. That fire was more than flame; it symbolized knowledge, creativity, reason, and the birth of human progress. From myth and philosophy to art and science, Prometheus became a symbol of rebellion, curiosity, and the power of enlightenment. This episode explores why his story still matters today and what it means to carry the fire of discovery, imagination, and truth in a modern world that often forgets its spark.
